comment.author: 79159520@N00
comment._content:
The vessel in the centre of the left hand photo is the paddle steamer DOVE which was one of three river gunboats built  by Yarrows of London for service on the Zambezi and Shire Rivers in the early 1890s when the British Protectorate was declared. The steamer's hull was used for many years as a ferry at Liwonde and in 1966 the hull was moved to Monkey Bay for use as a landing stage. Apparently the hull was still there in the early 70s.
Hard to identify the other two vessels. They appear to be propellor driven so the possibilities are  LIVINGSTONE, DOMIRA, PIONEER or ADVENTURE perhaps the QUEEN VICTORIA?

comment.author: 79159520@N00
comment._content: Closer scrutiny of the photo shows that both the screw steamers are, taking into account the quality of the image, identical.  Each vessel has an outward curved bow - a feature which only the gunboats PIONEER and ADVENTURE had - the other lake steamers had straight bows. There is a fine photo of the ADVENTURE in 'Lake Malawi Steamers' by P.A. Cole-King. Built by Yarrow & Co.  in 1891, the steamers were assembled and launched on Lake Malawi in 1893.
